docs.lead_paragraph: The unfolding drama that is Microsoft's blockbuster offer for Yahoo already features some of the tech world's bold-faced names, such as Steven Ballmer, Ray Ozzie, Jerry Yang and Terry Semel. The deal also includes some big-name investment banks as advisers -- but not necessarily on the sides you might expect.

docs.snippet: With competition for engineering talent in Silicon Valley as fierce as it has been since the late 1990s, if not fiercer, one crucial question about Microsoft's $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo is whether a combined company could more easily attract sof...
docs.lead_paragraph: With competition for engineering talent in Silicon Valley as fierce as it has been since the late 1990s, if not fiercer, one crucial question about Microsoft's $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo is whether a combined company could more easily attract software engineers - an increasingly precious commodity. Both companies are already fighting the perception that their most innovative days are behind them.

headline.main: Yahoo's Stock Spurts on False Rumors

docs.snippet: What if Microsoft dropped its bid for Yahoo and bought AOL and MySpace instead? One analyst says that may be a better deal than a target that doesn't want to merge....
docs.lead_paragraph: The flirtations and betrayals among Internet giants would steam up even the hottest afternoon soap opera. In the latest round, the News Corporation, which had been playing footsie with Yahoo, has jumped into the arms of Microsoft in an effort to break up the pending union of Yahoo and Time Warner's estranged wife, AOL. Oh yes, Google, which everyone envies, is prodding all this on to keep its rivals in a state of confusion.
docs.abstract: What if Microsoft dropped its bid for Yahoo and bought AOL and MySpace instead? One analyst says that may be a better deal than a target that doesn't want to merge.

headline.main: Is Yahoo the Odd Man Out?

docs.abstract: Over to you, Microsoft. Yahoo, confirming reports over the weekend that it would reject Microsoft's unsolicited takeover bid, said early Monday that its board had found the $44.6 billion offer was "not in the best interest of Yahoo! and our stockholders." In a short news release, Yahoo said the $31-per-share proposal "substantially undervalues" the Internet [...]
